sen.j: 女義太夫（おんなぎだゆう）は、女性による義太夫節語り。
sen.e: An onna-gidayu is a female reciter of Gidayu-bushi (musical narrative of the puppet theatre).
An onna-gidayu is a female reciter of Gidayu-bushi (musical narrative of the puppet theatre).
An onna-gidayu is a female reciter of Gidayu-bushi (musical narrative of the puppet theatre).

sen.j: 略して「女義（じょぎ）」と呼ぶ場合も多い。
sen.e: It is often shortened as "Jogi" ("jo" means a female).
It is often abbreviated as "Jogi" ("jo" means "a female").
It is often abbreviated as 'Jogi' ("jo" means "a female").

sen.j: 若い女性によって語られることから「娘義太夫（むすめぎだゆう）」という呼び方がかつては一般的であった。
sen.e: In the past, the term of Musume-gidayu (girl gidayu reciter) is typically used, because Gidayu-bushi was recited by young females.
In the past, the term "Musume-gidayu (girl gidayu reciter)" was typically used, because Gidayu-bushi was recited by young females.
In the past, the term 'Musume-gidayu (girl gidayu reciter)' was typically used, because Gidayu-bushi was recited by young females.

sen.j: 現在では、「女流義太夫（じょりゅうぎだゆう）」という呼び方がもっとも一般的である。
sen.e: Now, the term of Joryu-gidayu (also meaning female gidayu reciter) is typically used.
Today, however the term "Joryu-gidayu" (also meaning "female gidayu reciter") is typically used.
These days, the term 'Joryu-gidayu' (also meaning "female gidayu reciter") is typically used.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 過去にはまれに「たれ義太夫」ともいった。
sen.e: In the past, the term of "Tare gidayu" was also used, though rarely.
In the past, the term "Tare gidayu" was also used, albeit rarely.
In the past, the term 'Tare gidayu' was also used, although it was rarely.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 「女義太夫」という呼び方は、たとえば『演劇百科辞典』（平凡社）や『国史大辞典』（吉川弘文館）で「女義太夫」として立項されているが、21世紀に入ってからは「女流義太夫」が一般的である。
sen.e: The term of "Onna-gidayu" is listed, for example, in "Encyclopedia on theatrical arts" (published by Heibon-sha) or in "Kokushi Daijiten" (Great Dictionary of National History) (published by Yoshikawa Kobunkan), but entering the 21st century, the term of "Joryu-gidayu" is used generally.

The term "Onna-gidayu" is listed, for example, in "Encyclopedia of Theatrical Arts" (published by Heibon-sha) or in "Kokushi Daijiten (Great Dictionary of National History)" (published by Yoshikawa Kobunkan), but entering the twenty-first century, the term "Joryu-gidayu" is generally used.

The term 'Onna-gidayu' is listed in "Encyclopedia of Theatrical Arts (published by Heibon-sha)" or in "Kokushi Daijiten (Great Dictionary of National History)" (published by Yoshikawa Kobunkan), for example, but during the twenty-first century, the term 'Joryu-gidayu' is generally used.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 太夫1名と三味線1名で演奏されるのが基本である。
sen.e: Gidayu is basically performed by a tayu (a performer) and a shamisen (a three-stringed Japanese banjo) player.
Gidayu is basically performed by a tayu (a performer) and accompanied by a shamisen (three-string Japanese banjo) player.
Gidayu is generally performed by a tayu (a performer) and accompanied by a shamisen (three-string Japanese banjo) player.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 番組によっては、太夫と三味線も複数になることがあり、ほかに箏が加わることもある。
sen.e: Depending on the program, more than one tayu and more than one shamisen player participate in, with So (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) played sometimes as well.
Depending on the program, more than one tayu and more than one shamisen player participate, and sometimes a So (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) is played as well.
Depending on the program, more than one tayu and more than one shamisen player participate, and sometimes So (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) is played as well.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 娘義太夫での三味線は、太棹と呼ばれる三味線のなかでもっとも大型で、かつ音域が低いものが用いられる。
sen.e: The shamisen used in Gidayu is the largest of those called Futozao ("broad-neck" shamisen) with its tone range in a low frequency area.
The shamisen used in Gidayu is the largest of those called Futozao ("broad-neck" shamisen), and its range of tones is lower.
The shamisen used in Gidayu is the largest of those called Futozao ("broad-neck" shamisen), and its range of sounds is lower.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 演奏は、劇場、寄席などにおいて、多くの場合、素浄瑠璃にておこなう。
sen.e: The play is performed in a theater or yose mostly in the style of su-joruri (stand-alone joruri, the narration and shamisen accompaniment without puppets).
The play is performed in a theatre or yose, predominantly in the style of su-joruri (stand-alone joruri, meaning narration and shamisen accompaniment without puppets).
The play is performed in a theatre or storytellers' hall, predominantly in the style of su-joruri (stand-alone joruri, meaning narration and shamisen accompaniment without puppets).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 衣装は、夏は白、冬は白の着物に、大夫/三味線ともに揃いの肩衣と袴をつけておこなう。
sen.e: The players wear white costume in summer, and in winter, both the tayu and shamisen players wear white kimono with kataginu (short sleeveless garment made of hemp) and hakama (pleated and divided skirt made in fine stripes).

The players wear white costumes in summer, and in winter both the tayu and shamisen players wear white kimono with kataginu (short, sleeveless garments made of hemp) and hakama (pleated and divided skirts made in narrow strips).
sen.cmt: THEY SEEM LIKE WIDE STRIPS THAT ARE IN NARROW PLEATS.
sen.e: The players wear white costumes in summer, and in winter both the tayu and shamisen player wear white Japanese attire with short, sleeveless garments made of hemp and pleated and divided skirts made in narrow strips.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 人形などの団体と合同の公演もある。
sen.e: The play is sometimes performed jointly with a puppet-related organization.
The play is sometimes performed jointly with a puppet-related organization.
The play is sometimes performed jointly with an organization of puppet performers.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 「素浄瑠璃」は、人形/歌舞伎などが伴わない「浄瑠璃」の演奏形態である。
sen.e: "Su-joruri " is the play style of "pure joruri" with no puppet nor kabuki play accompanied.
"Su-joruri " is the play style of "pure joruri" without the accompaniment of puppets or kabuki.
Su-joruri' is a style of 'pure joruri' performance without the accompaniment of puppets or kabuki.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 浄瑠璃とは、簡単にいえば、物語性を重視した声楽で、複数の登場人物の詞（ことば）、背景説明、情景描写、心理描写などをすべて表現する「語りもの」である。
sen.e: To put it simply, pure joruri is vocal music placing emphasis on stories and can be said as one of narration plays in which, concerning a story, talks of characters, background explanations, the depiction of scenes, psychological descriptions are all made vocally.

To put it simply, pure joruri is vocal music that emphasizes stories and can be called a kind of narration play in which, concerning a story, the characters' words, background explanations, depictions of scenes and psychological descriptions are all expressed vocally.

To put it simply, pure joruri is vocal music that emphasizes stories and can be called a kind of narrative in which, concerning a story, the characters' words, background explanations, depictions of scenes and psychological descriptions are all expressed vocally.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 女流に対して、男流はなんという？ との疑問が予想されるが、演奏団体としては、近年世界遺産に登録された「文楽」（通称）がある。
sen.e: There would be a question that "How is Dan-ryu (gidayu performed by males) called corresponding to Jo-ryu (gidayu performed by females)?" and for this, there is (so-called) "Bunraku" registered to World Heritage recently.

One could ask, "How is Dan-ryu (gidayu performed by males) called corresponding to Jo-ryu (gidayu performed by females)?" and in response the so-called "Bunraku" has recently been registered as a World Heritage.

One could ask how Dan-ryu (gidayu performed by males) is called corresponding to Jo-ryu (gidayu performed by females), and the so-called 'Bunraku' which has recently been registered as a World Heritage will be the answer.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 女性による義太夫語りは、江戸後期の文化 (元号)文政ごろからおこなわれていたが、水野忠邦の天保の改革で女芸人が禁止されると廃れていった。
sen.e: Females became to narrate Gidayu in early 19th century in the latter half of the Edo period, but such plays by females declined after Tenpo Reforms by Tadakuni MIZUNO prohibited females to work as entertainers.

Females came to narrate Gidayu in the early nineteenth century, in the latter half of the Edo period, but such plays by females declined after the Tenpo reforms by Tadakuni MIZUNO prohibited females from working as entertainers.

Females came to narrate Gidayu in the early nineteenth century, during the latter half of the Edo period, but such plays by females declined after the Tenpo reforms by Tadakuni MIZUNO prohibited females from working as entertainers.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、明治維新以降の文化政策の改変のなかで、1877年の寄席取締規則によって女性の芸人が法的にも認められるようになる。
sen.e: However, in the movements for changing cultural policies in Meiji Restoration and later, females became to be able to work as entertainers legally based on the regulation for controlling yose (rakugo theaters) established in 1877.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in the movements to change cultural policies in the Meiji Restoration and later, females became able to work as entertainers legally, based on the regulation for controlling yose (rakugo theatres) established in 1877.

However, in and after the movements to change cultural policies in the Meiji Restoration, females became able to work as entertainers legally, based on the regulation for controlling yose (rakugo theatres) established in 1877.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: すると、江戸期以上の隆盛をみるようになる。
sen.e: Then guidayu played by females became more prosperous than in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus the guidayu played by females became more prosperous than in the Edo period.
Thus the guidayu performed by females became more prosperous than in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: いわゆる明治時代の後半期になると、大阪では豊竹呂昇、東京では竹本綾之助が空前の人気を博し、芸能での人気を歌舞伎と二分するほどになった。
sen.e: In the so-called latter half of the Meiji period, Rosho TOYOTAKE in Osaka and Ayanosuke TAKEMOTO in Tokyo gained unprecedented popularity, almost halving popularity with Kabuki in the entertainment world.
In the latter half of the Meiji period, Rosho TOYOTAKE in Osaka and Ayanosuke TAKEMOTO in Tokyo gained unprecedented popularity, nearly equaling that of kabuki in the entertainment world.
During the latter half of the Meiji period, Rosho TOYOTAKE in Osaka and Ayanosuke TAKEMOTO in Tokyo gained unprecedented popularity, nearly equaling that of kabuki in the entertainment world.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 当時、娘義太夫の日本髪が熱演のあまり乱れ、内容が佳境にさしかかると、客席のいる書生らの熱心な見物から、「どうする、どうする」と声がかかった。
sen.e: At that time, when musume-gidayu's Japanese coiffure became disheveled due to her enthusiastic performance and the story entered the most interesting part, spectators like students voiced "Dosuru (How do you do your hair?), Dosuru (How do you do your hair?)" loudly.

At that time, when musume-gidayu's Japanese coiffure became disheveled due to her enthusiastic performance and the story entered the most interesting part, spectators such as students would call out loud, "Dosuru (How do you do your hair?), Dosuru (How do you do your hair?)."

At that time, when musume-gidayu's Japanese coiffure became disheveled due to her enthusiastic performance and the story entered the most interesting part, spectators such as students would call out loud, 'Dosuru (How do you do your hair?), Dosuru (How do you do your hair?).'

sen.j: このことから、そうした見物を「堂摺連＝どうするれん」と呼んだ。
sen.e: Therefore, these spectators were called "Dosuru group persons (a group of persons voicing "Dosuru")."
Therefore, these spectators were called "Dosuru group persons (a group of persons voicing 'Dosuru')."
Therefore, these spectators were called 'Dosuru ren (a group of persons voicing 'Dosuru').'
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 特に激しい者は手拍子を打ち、茶碗の底を擦り合わせて騒ぐほど熱狂したという。
sen.e: Some spectators are said to have been so enthusiastic that they clapped hands and made noise by rubbing the back of bowls each other.
Some spectators are said to have been so enthusiastic that they would clap their hands and make noise by rubbing the backs of bowls against each other.
Some spectators are said to have been so enthusiastic that they would clap their hands and make noise by rubbing the backs of bowls against each other.

sen.j: 日常生活のなかにも娘義太夫は根をおろした。
sen.e: Musume-gidayu took root in everyday lives as well.
Musume-gidayu took root in everyday life as well.
Musume-gidayu took hold in everyday life as well.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 社会主義者らの集会などでも、余興として娘義太夫を楽しむといったことがあった。
sen.e: Socialists also enjoyed sometimes performances of musume-joruri at their meetings as an entertainment.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Socialists would sometimes enjoy performances of musume-joruri as a form of entertainment at their meetings.
The socialists would sometimes enjoy performances of musume-gidayu as a form of entertainment at their meetings.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: たとえば『光』第1巻第11号（1906年4月）に掲載の「日本社会党茶話会」という記事中に、「……談終るや余興として某嬢の義太夫、……」といった報告がみられる。
sen.e: For example, in the article titled "A tea party of Japan Socialist Party" included in No. 11, Volume 1 of "Hikari" (Light) in 1906, the report describing "---When a talk ended, a musume-gidayu----- as an entertainment---" is recorded.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For example, in the article titled "A Tea Party of the Japan Socialist Party" included in No. 11, Volume 1 of "Hikari" (Light) in 1906, the report describing "... when a talk ended, a musume-gidayu... as an entertainment..." is recorded.

For example, in the article titled 'A Tea Party of the Japan Socialist Party' included in No. 11, Volume 1 of "Hikari" (Light) in April, 1906, it is reported '... when a talk ended, a musume-gidayu... as an entertainment...'
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1923年の関東大震災以降、娘義太夫の人気は急速に衰えた。
sen.e: After The Great Kanto Earthquake in 1923, the popularity of musume-gidayu declined rapidly.
Subsequent to the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923, the popularity of musume-gidayu declined rapidly.
After the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923, the popularity of musume-gidayu declined rapidly.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 現在では、国立演芸場や広小路亭で定期的に開催される女流義太夫演奏会をはじめ、さまざまな機会で女流義太夫を聴くことができ、ファン・支持者の裾野も徐々にではあるが広がりつつある。
sen.e: Nowadays, recitations by joryu-gidayu can be enjoyed in various opportunities in addition to the plays held regularly in National Engei Hall and in Hirokoji-tei, and the base of their fans and supporters has become wider, though gradually.

Nowadays, recitations by joryu-gidayu can be enjoyed in various venues in addition to the plays held regularly at National Engei Hall and in Hirokoji-tei, and the base of fans and supporters has gradually expanded.

Nowadays, recitations by joryu-gidayu can be enjoyed in various venues in addition to the performances held regularly at National Engei Hall and in Hirokoji-tei, and the base of fans and supporters has gradually expanded.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また、浄瑠璃の担当者が不足している地芝居に参加したり、一度上演が途絶えた地芝居の再興に協力する等の活動もおこなっている。
sen.e: In addition, joryu-gidayu do such activities as participating in the Jishibai (local Kabuki) where a sufficient number of joruri players are unavailable or as cooperating the reconstruction of the Jishibai whose performances had been stopped.

Additionally, joryu-gidayu perform such activities as participating in the Jishibai (local kabuki) where sufficient numbers of joruri players aren't available, or as cooperating in the reconstruction of the Jishibai, whose performances had been stopped.

Additionally, joryu-gidayu perform such activities as participating in the Jishibai (local kabuki) where sufficient numbers of joruri performers aren't available, or as cooperating in the reconstruction of the Jishibai, whose performances had been stopped.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: ビートたけしの祖母である北野うしは、竹本八重子という娘義太夫であった。
sen.e: The grandmother of Beat Takeshi, Ushi KITANO, was a musume-gidayu named Yaeko TAKEMOTO.
The grandmother of Beat Takeshi, Ushi KITANO, was a musume-gidayu called Yaeko TAKEMOTO.
Ushi KITANO, the grandmother of Beat Takeshi, was a musume-gidayu called Yaeko TAKEMOTO.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。
